Life is indeed full of struggle, whether we are reluctant or happy to face it. The higher the level of patience, the higher the victory and lessons that will be obtained. That is the sunnah of Allah that applies to the people of the past and the present.
text.4:
Furthermore, Allah warns, is there still a group of people who presume that those who continue to commit evil deeds will be able to weaken Allah, so that He is unable to bring retribution commensurate with their actions? Has the decree of the Lord not yet applied to the previous wrongdoers, where they were punished with a punishment befitting their sins?

According to Ibn 'Abbas, this verse was revealed as a rebuke to a number of polytheistic figures in Mecca who considered that whatever they did, no one would be able to retaliate against them. They were al-Walid bin al-Mugirah, Abu Jahal, al-Aswad, al-'as bin Hisyam, 'Utbah bin Rabi'ah, al-Walid bin 'Utbah, 'Utbah bin Abi Mu'aith, Handhalah bin Abu Sufyan, and al-'as bin Wa'il. Indeed, such a thought is wrong and untrue. Allah does not make anything in vain. He tests and educates mankind with various kinds of teachings, with the intention that they may obtain the bright, illuminating divine light (nur Ilahi).
text.5:
This verse explains that those who earnestly desire to meet Allah and receive the reward for their deeds on the Day of Judgment should perform good deeds and avoid all prohibitions that may incur His wrath. Because the reward for a person's deeds will surely come. Allah is All-Hearing and All-Knowing of a person's intentions and deeds. Therefore, this verse serves as a reminder for everyone to always intend to achieve what they desire, namely Allah's pleasure, and to instill a sense of fear in their hearts of His torment and punishment.

The meaning of "meeting Allah" in this verse is "obtaining blessings in Paradise as a reward for good deeds," where the pinnacle of that pleasure is seeing the Essence of Allah Himself. Meanwhile, Ibn 'Abbas interpreted it to mean "the Day of Resurrection and the Day of Reckoning." Clearly, the meaning contained in this verse encourages a person to prepare themselves by doing as many good deeds as possible and completely avoiding Allah's prohibitions. Thus, they will obtain eternal happiness in the Hereafter.

The majority of Quranic commentators (Jumhur ulama tafsir) interpret *liqa'ullah* as death, which is certain to come. However, the word above also contains the meaning of Allah's promise of reward for good deeds and punishment for evil deeds. Whether death or Allah's promise, both will surely come.
text.6:
Allah explains that someone who sincerely strives (performs *jihad*), which is one aspect of expressing longing to meet Allah, in reality, that struggle is for themselves, not for Allah. *Jihad* means fighting the enemy and fighting one's own desires. It can also mean exerting all efforts for Allah and does not only mean war.

The person who will obtain the results of their struggle is the one who bases their intention on obtaining a reward from Allah, the Lord of the universe. Allah does not need whether they will strive for Himself or not strive at all, because He is the Most Rich, free from all of His creation. He is the One Who controls all of this universe and acts according to His own will.

The essence of *jihad* is patience, both *jihad* in fighting the enemy and *jihad* in controlling desires. A person who is patient in performing *jihad* means being resilient in facing trials and remaining steadfast to the truth that they have believed in. In addition, they also strive to overcome obstacles in upholding that truth. In other verses, Allah affirms that the practical benefit of a person's deeds is truly for their own benefit.

As Allah says:

Whoever does righteousness, it is for his own (benefit); and whoever does evil, it is against himself. And your Lord is never unjust to (His) servants. (Fussilat/41: 46)

And Allah says:

If you do good, you do good for yourselves; and if you do evil, (it is) for yourselves. (al-Isra'/17: 7)
text.7:
Then Allah explains that those who believe in Allah and His Messenger with true faith, even when tested with various trials, do not revert to disbelief (apostasy). Likewise, when experiencing suffering in dealing with polytheists, they continue to fulfill all their obligations, avoid all prohibitions, increase their piety (taqwa), help those in distress, defend the oppressed, defend and protect the country from enemy attacks, and cooperate with one another. They receive a reward from Allah in the form of forgiveness for all their past sins and mistakes. All of this is a cause for the multiplication of rewards that Allah gives, becoming tenfold.

Allah says:

"Whoever comes [on the Day of Judgment] with a good deed will have ten times the like thereof [to his credit], and whoever comes with an evil deed will not be recompensed except the like thereof; and they will not be wronged." (al-An'am/6: 160)
text.8:
Allah commands humans to be good to their parents (mother and father). The way to be good is by providing sustenance (expenses), caring for, and respecting them with love, unless they invite one to commit shirk. So, the limit of being good is as long as the things commanded do not involve acts containing elements of shirk. In another verse it is also mentioned:

And your Lord has decreed that you worship none but Him, and that you be dutiful to your parents. If one of them or both of them attain old age in your life, say not to them a word of disrespect, nor shout at them but address them in terms of honour. (al-Isra'/17: 23)

A similar explanation is also obtained in the verse:

And We have enjoined on man to be good to his parents; in pain did his mother bear him, and in pain did she give him birth. And the carrying of the child to his weaning is thirty months. When he attains full maturity and reaches forty years, he says, "My Lord, enable me to be grateful for Your favor which You have bestowed upon me and upon my parents and to do righteousness of which You approve. And make righteous for me my offspring. Indeed, I have repented to You, and indeed, I am of the Muslims." (al-Ahqaf/46: 15)

To obtain a comprehensive understanding of the meaning obtained in the verse above, one can pay attention to Allah's explanation in the verse below:

And We have enjoined upon man [care] for his parents. His mother carried him, [increasing her] in weakness upon weakness, and his weaning is in two years. Be grateful to Me and to your parents; to Me is the [final] destination. But if they endeavor to make you associate with Me that of which you have no knowledge, do not obey them but accompany them in [this] world with appropriate kindness and follow the way of those who turn back to Me [in repentance]. Then to Me will be your return, and I will inform you about what you used to do. (Luqman/31: 14-15)

Regarding the prohibition of obeying creatures in committing disobedience, it is mentioned in a sahih hadith, namely:

There is no obedience to a creature (human) in disobeying the Creator (Khaliq). (Narrated by Ahmad from Ali bin Abi thalib)

The meaning of the phrase "that of which you have no knowledge" in the verse is the absence of knowledge about matters of divinity or ilahiyah. In other words, it is not permissible to obediently follow someone, as long as one does not know about the matter being followed. Therefore, it is not permissible to imitate something that is clearly wrong. Furthermore, it is said that all humans will return to Allah on the Day of Judgment, both the disbelievers and the believers, both those who are good to their parents and those who are disobedient. All deeds done in the world will be rewarded by Allah, those who do good will be rewarded with goodness, and those who do evil will be rewarded with evil as well.
text.9:
Then, the position of those who believe and do good deeds, and those who constantly purify their souls, is reaffirmed. They will be included in the group of righteous people and placed in the "Jannatun na'im" (Gardens of Bliss).

Allah includes them in the group of righteous people as a reward bestowed upon anyone who chooses to heed the commands of Allah and His Messenger rather than the disobedient commands of their parents. A child's refusal to follow their parents' commands will inevitably lead to strained relations between the two parties. For this reason, Allah promises the child that they will be given a better replacement, namely, they will be included in the group of righteous people.

As-shalihin here refers to the group of people who are very devoted to Allah and who join the group of prophets and others, as mentioned in Allah's word in Surah an-Nisa'/4: 69:

And whoever obeys Allah and the Messenger (Muhammad) - those will be with the ones upon whom Allah has bestowed favor - of the prophets, the steadfast affirmers of truth, the martyrs and the righteous. And excellent are those as companions. (an-Nisa'/4: 69)
text.10:
According to a narration, these verses were revealed concerning an event that happened to a person named 'Ayyash bin Abi Rabi'ah, who initially embraced Islam and then migrated to Medina. However, due to his conversion to Islam, he experienced various forms of torture. Unable to endure it any longer, he apostatized and reverted to being a polytheist. The people who tortured him were the prominent figures of the Quraysh infidels, Abu Jahal and al-Harith. Both were his own uncles (his mother's younger brothers). Eventually, 'Ayyash re-embraced Islam and became a good Muslim.

This verse explains the state of a person who claims to believe in Allah and proclaims His oneness with his tongue. However, if he is slandered or tortured by polytheists who are displeased with his Islam, he considers the slander, in the form of trials and tribulations from others, to be the same as the torment from God in the Hereafter. Therefore, rather than experiencing continuous torture, he prefers to revert to idol worship (apostatize).

In reality, if he truly believed, he would certainly be patient with the trials and comfort his heart with the faith that resides within his chest. However, the trials actually turn his heart away from believing in Allah, just as Allah's punishment turns a person away from his disbelief. He assumes that the torture from humans is unavoidable, while the punishment of Allah in the Hereafter can be avoided. In another verse it is stated:

And of the people is he who worships Allah on an edge. If good befalls him, he is content therewith; but if a trial befalls him, he turns back on his face [to unbelief]. He has lost [this] world and the Hereafter. That is what is the manifest loss. (al-Hajj/22: 11)

If Allah's help is brought to the believers who are struggling, then those who are still doubtful about the truth of Islam pretend to be good friends and say, "We are always with you as brothers in religion, and we will help you in facing the enemy." What they say is nothing but mere words from their mouths. For they have lied about what they have claimed. The explanation of another verse confirms:

Those who wait and watch about you; then if there is a victory for you from Allah, they say, "Were we not with you?" And if there is a victory for the disbelievers, they say, "Did we not gain the advantage over you and protect you from the believers?" Allah will judge between you on the Day of Resurrection, and never will Allah grant to the disbelievers a way [to triumph] over the believers. (an-Nisa'/4: 141)
text.11:
Allah warns against such attitudes and affirms that He knows everything that is etched in their hearts. Nothing is hidden. In short, Allah knows the true nature of the hypocrites' hearts, even though they constantly profess their faith. They cannot deceive Allah in this way. The *fitnah* in the form of trials and tribulations serves only to distinguish those who believe, who are truly pure in their faith, from those who are hypocritical. Those who truly believe will obey Allah in all circumstances and situations. Those who are steadfast and patient in the face of suffering will obtain victory and a fitting reward from Allah. Conversely, the hypocrites will return to disobeying Him when they are afflicted with trials or when they feel the burdens and obligations placed upon them are too heavy, so that their hearts cannot bear to perform them. Further explanation can be found in verse 12 of this surah, and in the verse:

"Allah will not leave the believers in the state in which you are now, until He distinguishes the evil from the good. Nor will Allah disclose to you the unseen, but Allah chooses of His messengers whom He wills. So believe in Allah and His messengers. And if you believe and fear Allah, then for you is a great reward." (ali 'Imran/3:179)
text.12:
According to Mujahid, this verse was revealed to expose the efforts of the Quraysh to persuade their people who had believed by saying, "We and you will not be resurrected. Therefore, follow our steps. If you are sinful because of this action, we will bear that sin." In connection with this, Allah warns the believers that the disbelievers are lying. Because on the Day of Judgment, no one is allowed to bear the sins of others. Allah affirms:

And no bearer of burdens will bear the burden of another. And if one heavily laden calls (another) to (bear) his load, not a bit of it will be carried, even though he be a near relative. (Fathir/35: 18)

And the word of Allah:

Though they will be shown each other, the criminal will wish that he could ransom himself from the punishment of that Day through his children. (al-Ma'arij/70: 11)

At the end of this verse, Allah reaffirms that they are liars. Imam az-Zamakhsyari interprets that among those who invite their colleagues to commit sin, there are also those who claim to be Muslims. They promise to bear the punishment so that foolish people and those with weak faith are tempted by these subtle enticements and seductions.
text.13:
Regarding the invitations and enticements of the disbelievers, Allah affirms that their seductions are of no benefit to them. These enticements are conveyed in an effort to invite others to disbelief and error, for which they must bear the sin, as well as the sin of those who act upon their enticements. However, those who act on their own will not have their sins reduced, even if the punishment of those who invited them is multiplied. In this verse, it is reaffirmed:

"(That they may) bear their own burdens in full on the Day of Resurrection and some of the burdens of those whom they misguide without knowledge. How evil is that which they bear!" (an-Nahl/16: 25)

In a hadith narrated by Muslim from Abu Hurairah, the Messenger of Allah said:

"Whoever calls to guidance will have a reward like that of those who follow him, without it detracting from their reward in the slightest. And whoever calls to misguidance will have a sin like that of those who follow him, without it detracting from their sin in the slightest." (Narrated by Muslim from Abu Hurairah).

At the end of this verse, Allah affirms that in the Hereafter, they will be held accountable for the falsehoods they committed in the world. They will be asked questions with a tone of contempt about the people they deceived with their lies, causing them to go astray.
text.14:
The stories of the prophets begin with recounting the struggle of Prophet Noah. He is the father of the prophets. He preached, calling his people to believe in Allah, the One and Only, and to believe in his prophethood for nine hundred and fifty years. Nevertheless, he never grew tired of inviting them, both day and night. Sometimes with a gentle voice, but often with a loud voice conveying Allah's threat against their disbelief. However, his efforts were unsuccessful. Only a handful of them were willing to believe. The rest rejected and denied him. Therefore, Allah punished them. A punishment called "The Flood of Prophet Noah" was sent, in the form of a flood that drowned them all. No one was saved from Allah's punishment except those who believed and joined Noah's ark.

Al-Hakim narrates:

It is narrated from Ibn 'Abbas that he said, "Allah sent Prophet Noah when he was 40 years old and he preached to his people for 950 years, calling them to follow the religion of Allah, and Prophet Noah lived after the flood (deluge) for 60 years, so that the number of people became many and spread out." (Riwayat al-hakim)
text.15:
Allah saved Noah and his followers with an ark that he had built. The existence of Prophet Noah's ark serves as an example and lesson for those who came after, because it landed, still intact, on a hill called Mount Judi. For some time, Prophet Noah's ark could still be seen by people who visited the site in its entirety. This made people aware of Allah's blessings bestowed upon the believers by saving them from the danger of the flood. This is stated in another verse which reads:

"Indeed, when the water overflowed, We carried you in the ship. That We might make it a reminder for you and that conscious ears might be conscious of it." (al-Haqqah/69: 11-12)

The lesson that can be learned from the story above is that the messengers after Noah need not feel sad because their people rejected the truth of the revelation they brought. Torture and obstacles from the disbelieving and polytheistic people who are not pleased with Islam are a warning to believers that even if those polytheists torture and hurt them in this world, in the end, everything will return to God. Those polytheists return to face disaster and misery in the blazing fire of hell, while those who believe and are patient in facing suffering return to a noble place with the full help of Allah.

Such is the lesson from the story of Prophet Noah. The disbelievers who had hurt Noah and his people were ultimately drowned by God in the flood, but the believers with Noah were saved, sailing on the ark. Noah's patience in preaching for a long time should be a lesson for every preacher. In fact, we should have even greater patience than Noah, because our age and time for preaching is not as long as the age of Prophet Noah.
text.16:
Allah commanded Prophet Muhammad to relate to his people the story of Prophet Ibrahim. After reaching adulthood, with the perfect growth of his intellect, capable of thinking and analyzing things objectively, and having reached the perfect degree of prophethood, Ibrahim began to devote his attention to calling people to accept the truth he brought. He invited them to single out Allah in worship and purify themselves from all forms of polytheism (shirk). He also called on them to sincerely serve Allah, whether alone or in the presence of others, and to avoid Allah's wrath by carrying out all the duties and obligations He commanded, and avoiding all His prohibitions.

All of this was Allah's command that Ibrahim had to convey to his people. What he conveyed was the best, if only they had a little knowledge. With that knowledge, they could distinguish between good and bad, and how to seek or obtain as much benefit as possible for this world and the hereafter. Then Ibrahim showed them the misery that befalls those who seek a god other than Allah.
text.17:
In this verse, Allah affirms that deities besides Him are clearly the product of human hands, yet they lie by considering them to be true gods. They believe that their creations, in the form of statues and idols, are capable of providing benefit or advantage to them. Ibrahim rebukes and condemns their belief because those statues are not capable of providing sustenance to them in the slightest. Sustenance is an absolute authority that only Allah possesses. Therefore, they are encouraged to ask for sustenance and income only from Allah, and then be grateful if what is requested has been granted by Him. Only Allah brings sustenance to humans and all the blessings to His servants. Humans are encouraged to seek His pleasure by drawing closer to Him.

This verse is concluded with the phrase "to Him you will be returned," meaning that humans must prepare to meet Allah by worshiping and being grateful. Every human will be held accountable for all their deeds and all the blessings they receive.
text.18:
Ibrahim again warned his people that if they affirmed what had been conveyed to them, they would surely be happy. Conversely, they would suffer harm and misery if they continued to deny the prophet's call, as experienced by those before them who denied God's messengers. Among them were the people of Prophet Nuh, Prophet Hud, and Prophet Saleh. They were all punished by Allah because of their disobedience. On the other hand, Allah saved the believers along with His messengers.

This verse concludes with the affirmation that the task and mission of the messenger is to convey the manifest truth to mankind. Whether they affirm or reject it, it has no consequence for the messenger himself. No authority has been given by Allah to any messenger to force people to believe in his call. Whether they want to affirm it or continue to deny it is beyond his responsibility.
text.19:
Some scholars view this verse as directed towards the inhabitants of Mecca who refused to believe in the Messenger of Allah. However, the majority of commentators (jumhur mufassir) are of the opinion that this verse is still a continuation of Prophet Ibrahim's warning to his people.

Here, Allah affirms that if the disbelievers still do not believe in Allah, the One and Only, as conveyed by His messengers, then they are invited to observe and contemplate the process of their own creation from beginning to end. Allah created mankind starting from the process in the mother's womb for six or nine months, or more. After birth, humans are equipped with the ability to hear, see, and reason. To guarantee their sustenance, Allah facilitates sources of provision to support the continuity of their lives. When destiny arrives, Allah causes them to die through the angels assigned to do so. For Allah, resurrecting mankind is as easy as creating them. Allah affirms in another verse:

"And it is He who begins creation; then He will repeat it, and that is easier for Him. And to Him belongs the loftiest description in the heavens and earth. And He is the Exalted in Might, the Wise." (ar-Rum/30: 127)

In essence, this verse warns that humans should be able to understand how easy it is for Allah to create mankind. But why do they not believe in the Day of Resurrection when it is actually easier for Allah?
text.20:
If humans still do not understand the meaning of the above verse, Allah encourages them to travel and visit other places while observing and contemplating how Allah is powerful in creating His creatures. Humans are also commanded to observe the structure of the heavens and the earth, as well as the millions of glittering stars. Some remain in their positions, but rotate on their orbital lines. Likewise, the mountains and vast lands that Allah created as places to live. A variety of plants and fruits, rivers and vast oceans. All of this, when contemplated, will make a person realize how Almighty Allah is, the Creator of all that.

Then, is it fitting for us not to believe that to give life and death to weak humans is a very easy thing for Allah? Likewise, to resurrect them in the second life (the afterlife) is also not a difficult matter for Allah. In another verse, Allah further explains:

"We will show them Our signs in the horizons and within themselves until it becomes clear to them that it is the truth. But is it not sufficient concerning your Lord that He is, over all things, a Witness?" (Fussilat/41: 53)

Likewise, we find a verse that reads:

"That is Allah, your Lord, Creator of all things; there is no deity except Him, so how are you deluded?" (al-Mu'min/40: 62)
text.21:
Hearing the advice presented by that man and seeing his attitude that displayed honesty and sincerity, Musa immediately departed in a state of constant vigilance, because behind him some of Pharaoh's soldiers were preparing to surround and capture him. How heavy was the pressure Musa suffered. Nevertheless, he continued to try to save himself and prayed to Allah, "O my Lord, the Almighty, the Most Compassionate, the Most Merciful, deliver me from the clutches of the oppressive people of Pharaoh." Allah answered his prayer and showed him the way to Madyan.

According to a narration, Pharaoh ordered his soldiers to pursue Musa even into the small roads and forbade them from using the main roads because he was sure that Musa would not take that route.
text.22: Nothing can overcome or match the power of Allah. Allah is in control of all His servants. All creatures are in need of Him. Even if someone were to seek refuge in the high heavens, or hide in the belly of a fish in the sea, he would not be able to escape the grasp of Allah's power. Therefore, no one among mankind can find a helper who will deliver him from the punishment and torment of Allah, neither in the heavens nor on the earth.
text.23: After explaining the three fundamental issues in Islam which are part of the pillars of faith, Allah threatens the disbelievers who refuse to affirm His explanations above, that they will not receive Allah's mercy, causing them to despair. Because they deny the Oneness of Allah, reject the messengers sent to them, and do not believe in the Day of Resurrection, it means they do not fear the threat of Allah's punishment and do not expect a good reward from Him. Therefore, it is fitting that they are threatened with a painful punishment, in this world and the hereafter.
text.24: Quickly, Moses drew water for the two girls so they could water their sheep. Exhausted, he sought shelter under a tree, feeling hunger and thirst because he had not eaten for several days except for leaves. Moses prayed to Allah because he was in great need of His mercy and compassion, to eliminate the suffering he was experiencing.
text.25:
After being saved, Ibrahim approached his people again with an attitude of rebuking and criticizing the gods they worshipped. "Indeed, you worship these idols only to maintain affection among yourselves. You feel intimate and closer because of worshipping them. Yet, there is not the slightest reason that can justify that worship," Ibrahim said, teaching his people. On the contrary, on the Day of Judgment, that affectionate relationship will turn into an atmosphere of mutual accusation and hatred, even mutual cursing, both between close friends and between those who follow (the people) and those who are followed (the leaders). The only thing they can no longer hope for is help from Allah. This will not happen to those who believe and are righteous.

Allah says:

"Close friends, that Day, will be enemies to each other, except for the righteous." (az-Zukhruf/43: 67)
text.26:
In this verse, a servant of Allah named Lut, namely Lut bin Haran, is mentioned. He was the nephew of Prophet Ibrahim. After witnessing the greatness of Allah's miracle upon Prophet Ibrahim (not being burned by the fire), he immediately declared his faith. Ibrahim joyfully welcomed his first follower with the words, "I will make the land of Sham as the village to which I will migrate."

According to historical accounts, the village that Ibrahim made his place of migration was in the region of Kufah, from Kutsa to the land of Sham. Lut's faith grew stronger as he received guidance from Allah, even though he lived in an environment of a society that was chaotic, wasting time, and engaging in useless activities. If Ibrahim remained silent without carrying out his da'wah duties, it would be a sign of disapproval of the evil deeds committed by his people. Ibrahim said in his heart that if he remained in his country, he would be wasting his time in vain. Based on this consideration, Ibrahim migrated to the land of Sham.

Imam al-Baihaqi narrated from Anas bin Malik that among the first Muslims (during the time of the Messenger of Allah saw) to migrate with their families was the companion Uthman bin 'Affan:

It is narrated from Anas bin Malik, he said, "Uthman, along with his wife Ruqayah, the daughter of the Messenger of Allah, migrated to the land of Abyssinia. Then the Messenger of Allah was delayed in receiving news about their situation in Abyssinia, even though he was hoping for news from them. Then a woman conveyed news about 'Uthman and his daughter to the Prophet, and the Messenger of Allah then said, 'Uthman is the first person to migrate with his family to Allah after Prophet Lut.'" (Narrated by ath-Thabrani)

Based on the hadith above, it is clear that Lut was the first person who was forced to migrate with Ibrahim in order to save his religion. The reason Ibrahim migrated was because Allah alone had the power to provide him with help. Allah prevents the intentions of someone who wants to do evil to him. He is All-Wise in managing the affairs of His creatures, and everything they strive for. Another reason is that Ibrahim's country was no longer conducive to maintaining the faith of his followers.
text.27:
In this verse, Allah recounts some of the blessings that He bestowed upon Ibrahim in this world and the Hereafter as a reward for his sincerity in his deeds. These blessings include:

a. Ibrahim was blessed with a son named Isaac. Isaac would later be blessed with a son named Jacob. Both were appointed as prophets, as Allah says:

"So when he had withdrawn from them and that which they worshipped other than Allah, We granted him Isaac and Jacob, and each of them We made a prophet." (Maryam/19:49)

In another verse, it is also explained:

"And We bestowed upon him Isaac and Jacob as a gift, and each of them We made righteous." (al-Anbiya'/21:72)

The high status of Ibrahim, Isaac, and Jacob was also emphasized by the Messenger of Allah in his saying:

"Indeed, the one who is said to be noble is the son of a noble person, the son of a noble person, the son of a noble person, namely Yusuf bin Yakub bin Ishak bin Ibrahim." (Narrated by al-Bukhari and Muslim from Abu Hurairah)

b. From the lineage of Ibrahim's descendants, people were born who attained the degree of *nubuwwah* (prophethood) by receiving revelation. From his son Isaac came Jacob, Yusuf, and Jesus, and from Ismail came the Prophet Muhammad.

c. Ibrahim was granted rewards in this world. The *mufassirun* (interpreters of the Quran) explain that the meaning of "rewards in this world" here is numerous descendants who changed the beliefs of their followers from misguided nations to nations that received guidance. From among his descendants, many attained the degree of prophethood. Ibrahim's name is mentioned in the *tahiyyat* (greetings) when performing *salat* (prayer), and his name is known as the "father of the prophets," where previously he was a man who was not so well known. This is affirmed by Allah in the verse that reads:

"They said, "Who has done this to our gods? Indeed, he is of the wrongdoers." They said, "We heard a youth mentioning them who is called Ibrahim." (al-Anbiya'/21:59-60)

Prophet Ibrahim is the only prophet who obtained the title "Khalilullah" (the beloved of Allah).

d. On the Day of Judgment, Ibrahim will be included in the ranks of the righteous. This means that the reward for his goodness and piety will be perfected for him. Also, his reward will be perfected by giving him various advantages. Moreover, he will achieve victory by attaining several high degrees in the sight of the Lord of the Universe.

In short, Allah has bestowed upon Ibrahim various kinds of happiness in this world and the Hereafter.
text.28: Allah commanded the Prophet Muhammad to relate the story of Prophet Lut. He was sent to a people residing in the land of Sodom. Lut himself resided in that land. He married one of the daughters of that people, thus Lut had a relationship of in-laws with them. Lut stated firmly to his people that what they had been doing was considered a *fahisyah* (evil and reprehensible act). The term sodomy, which is popular today, originates from the name of the city where Lut's people committed that reprehensible act. What they did had never been done by previous communities, as explained in the following verse about the type of act they committed.
text.29:
The people of Lot enjoyed indulging their lust with other men. This habit clearly contradicted the purpose of normal human biological needs. Normal sexual desire stimulates men to satisfy their lust with women. Lot strongly condemned this act and advised his people to abandon this cursed behavior. The inhabitants of Sodom also enjoyed committing robbery and murder on roads traversed by caravans carrying merchandise. Their goods were seized, and then the owners were killed. In addition, their words and deeds in places of assembly were disgusting, damaging the foundations of noble morals and ethics, and sound thinking. The Prophet Muhammad said:

Narrated from Ummu Hani binti Abu Thalib, who asked the Messenger of Allah, "O Messenger of Allah, what is your opinion about the meaning of the verse "You commit evil in your meeting places" (al-'Ankabut/29: 29), what evil did they commit?" He explained that they enjoyed mocking people who passed by on the road and humiliating them. (Riwayat al-hakim)

Lot did not remain silent seeing the imbalances that occurred in his people's society. He tried to prevent them by giving valuable advice and teachings. However, they regarded all of that as trivial and never heeded it.

When Lot threatened his people that Allah would send down punishment if they did not change their vile behavior, they instead challenged him. If it was true that God would bring His punishment, they challenged Lot to ask God to send down the promised punishment right now. "We will prove how far the truth of your words goes, O Lot," they also asserted. Because of their deep hatred, they expelled Lot from their land. Because there was no use for holy people like him to live with them. Allah explains:

And the answer of his people was none other than saying, "Expel them (Lot and his followers) from your city; indeed, they are men who keep themselves pure." (al-A'raf/7: 82)

The people of Lot challenged him to bring the punishment. Prophet Lot finally pleaded for Allah to help him.

The verse above illustrates how harsh their attitude of disbelief and stubbornness was, to the point that they dared to expel the messenger of God from their own land.
text.30: Lut then came to the conclusion that his people were no longer likely to accept his call. He no longer hoped that his people would receive guidance from Allah. At that moment, Lut prayed to Allah to help him face and eradicate the evil and rotten deeds that had become ingrained in the lives of his society, and had become a hereditary culture. They considered Lut's threats as mere bluffs. Therefore, Allah truly answered Lut's prayer. Allah then sent upon them a rain of stones from the sky, so they were all destroyed. This was due to their wickedness and disbelief.
text.31: In this verse, Allah explains the arrival of angels who met Prophet Ibrahim. They gave him the good news that Allah would grant him a son named Isaac. Later, that son would be appointed as a prophet and messenger, replacing Ibrahim's duties and position. Then, he was informed that the land of Sodom would be destroyed to punish the people who denied Lut and acted unjustly.
text.32: Ibrahim felt worried and anxious about Lut's fate, because Lut might also be destroyed along with them. Therefore, he reminded those who were assigned by Allah of this. Ibrahim said, "O angels, there is a messenger of Allah named Lut there. He is not among those who wrong themselves, but rather he is a messenger who believes and is obedient to Him." The angels replied, "Yes, we are aware of that, and Lut is not included in the group of evil people. However, his wife is among those who will certainly be punished, because she also affirmed the people of Lut in their disbelief, injustice, and vile deeds."
text.33:
When the angels came to Lut and conveyed the purpose of their arrival, Lut panicked and became breathless. This was because he feared that the people of Sodom would harass him later if they found out about the noble guests. Therefore, he deliberately kept the arrival of the angels a secret. Lut could not refuse their arrival. After seeing Lut's fear and anxiety over the arrival of his people, the angels reassured him by saying, "O Lut, be calm, do not be upset. You do not need to worry about our safety and what your people will do to us. Because their evil deeds have reached their peak and you have given them enough advice."

To further reassure Lut, the angels also said, "We will save you from the torment that will be sent down upon your people in the near future, as well as your followers who are faithful and loyal. Inevitably, they will experience severe torment. And your wife is among those who will be punished."

Lut's wife knew that there were male guests staying at her house, so she immediately informed her colleagues about it. As a result, the news spread quickly that there were unknown guests in Lut's house. Immediately, evil intentions arose in their hearts to disturb the guests. They then discussed and agreed on a plan to carry out this intention. Thus, it became clear that Lut's wife was among those who participated in the evil plan.

The angel's explanation above calmed Lut's feelings of fear. He was reminded again, "We angels will certainly bring punishment upon them with our own hands, as a result of the wickedness that is deeply rooted within them."

The well-known opinion mentions that initially there was a violent shaking, and the land where the wicked people lived was turned upside down. After being attacked by a rain of stones and a terrible earthquake, the land was destroyed and flattened to the ground. Finally, the land of Sodom, the former residence of the people of Prophet Lut, became the Dead Sea (al-Bahrul Mayit).
text.34:
When the angels came to Lut and conveyed the purpose of their arrival, Lut panicked and felt suffocated. This was because he feared that the people of Sodom would harass him later if they knew there were noble guests. Therefore, he deliberately kept the arrival of the angels a secret. Lut could not refuse their arrival. After seeing Lut's fear and anxiety over the arrival of his people, the angels reassured him by saying, "O Lut, be calm, do not be agitated. You do not need to worry about our safety and what your people will do to us. Because their evil deeds have reached their peak and you have given them enough advice."

To further reassure Lut, the angels also said, "We will save you from the torment that will be sent down upon your people in the near future, as well as your followers who are faithful and loyal. Inevitably, they will experience severe torment. And your wife is among those who will be punished."

Lut's wife knew that there were male guests staying at her house, so she immediately informed her colleagues about it. As a result, the news spread quickly that there were unknown guests in Lut's house. Immediately, evil intentions arose in their hearts to disturb the guests. They then discussed and agreed on a plan to carry out their intentions. Thus, it became clear that Lut's wife was among those who participated in the evil plan.

The angels' explanation above calmed Lut's feelings of fear. He was reminded again, "We angels will certainly bring torment upon them with our own hands, as a result of the wickedness that has taken root in them."

The well-known opinion states that initially there was a violent shaking, and the land where the wicked people lived was turned upside down. After being attacked by a rain of stones and a terrible earthquake, the land was destroyed and leveled to the ground. Finally, the land of Sodom, the former residence of the people of Prophet Lut, became the Dead Sea (al-Bahrul Mayit).
text.35: Then it is explained that in addition to punishing the mistakes that had been made by the people of Lot, the torment and calamity were also sent down in the hope that they would serve as a warning to subsequent generations, namely those who use their intellect and want to learn from what has happened.
text.36: Allah sent the Prophet Shu'aib to a people residing in the land of Madyan, so that they would worship Allah, the One and Only, with sincerity. This worship would be beneficial for happiness in life in this world and in the Hereafter. In this verse, it is said, "hope for (the reward of) the Last Day," meaning you should fear the coming of that Day and prepare yourselves with as many righteous deeds as possible to face it. In addition to the call to worship Allah, the One and Only, and to increase good deeds as provisions for the abode of the Hereafter, Shu'aib also encouraged them to abandon all destructive and ruinous actions. Do not harm one another, such as by reducing measures and weights, and robbing passing caravans. Then they were also commanded to increase repentance to their Lord while returning to Him by carrying out His commands and avoiding His prohibitions.
text.37: However, just like the people of Prophet Lut, the people of Prophet Syuaib were also disobedient and unwilling to accept Prophet Syuaib's advice. They even denied him. Therefore, the sunnah of Allah prevailed. When they openly denied Syuaib after being given repeated warnings, the time came for Allah to punish them. The land where they lived was shaken by a terrifying earthquake that destroyed their dwellings. They died face down and were swallowed by the earth, without moving again. A more complete story about Prophet Syuaib has also been mentioned by God in other verses, namely in Surah Al-A'raf/7: 88-93, Hud/11: 87-94, and asy-Syu'ara'/26: 176-190.
text.38: However, just like the people of Prophet Lut, the people of Prophet Syuaib were also disobedient and unwilling to accept Prophet Syuaib's advice. They even denied him. Therefore, Allah's sunnah (established pattern) took effect. When they openly denied Syuaib after being repeatedly warned, the time came for Allah to punish them. The land where they lived was shaken by a terrifying earthquake that destroyed their dwellings. They died face down and were swallowed by the earth, without moving again. A more complete story about Prophet Syuaib has also been mentioned by God in other verses, namely in Surah Al-A'raf/7: 88-93, Hud/11: 87-94, and asy-Syu'ara'/26: 176-190.
text.39: Moses had explained to Qarun, Pharaoh, and Haman the signs of the greatness of Allah's verses as a basis for strengthening the message he brought. Nevertheless, they were arrogant or takabur and unwilling to believe. Pharaoh's arrogance had truly exceeded all bounds. He considered himself a god who must be worshipped. Therefore, they were all not spared from Allah's torment in various punishments.
text.40:
Allah destroyed the previous nations who denied the messengers by sending down various kinds of torment, including:

a. A very strong wind carrying stones, which was brought upon the 'Ad people. They challenged Prophet Hud, "Who is mightier than us in strength?" Their arrogance was answered by God by sending a wind, so that they died prostrate. Allah says in another verse explaining about the torment, namely:

"And as for 'Ad, they were destroyed by a furious wind, exceedingly violent. He subjected it to them for seven nights and eight days in succession, so you would see the people therein fallen as if they were hollow trunks of palm trees. Then do you see of them any remnant remaining?" (al-Haqqah/69: 6-8)

b. A thunderous sound that shattered eardrums. This torment was sent down to the Thamud people. They still rebelled, refusing to believe in Prophet Saleh. Suddenly they fainted and died from the shock of a thunderous sound that was very terrible. Allah explains further:

"And as for Thamud, they were destroyed by the overpowering cry." (al-Haqqah/69: 5)

c. Being swallowed by the earth, this is the story of Qarun, a wealthy man. Initially, he was a believer and obedient to Musa. Then after becoming rich, he became arrogant and disobedient. He committed transgressions beyond limits. Moreover, he refused to pay zakat as an obligation of wealth for the rich. Because of this arrogance, Allah punished him. The ground around where Qarun stood shook, collapsed, and gradually swallowed Qarun's body until it completely disappeared from the face of the earth.

Allah's word:

"So We caused the earth to swallow him and his home. And there was for him no company to aid him other than Allah, nor was he of those who could defend themselves." (al-Qasas/28: 81)

d. Being drowned in water. This is the punishment for the people of Prophet Nuh along with all their wealth. Besides the people of Prophet Nuh, Pharaoh, Haman and his troops also drowned in the Red Sea as a reward for their arrogance and the torment they inflicted on Musa and his followers. Allah's word about Nuh in Surah al-Anbiya'/21: 76-77:

"And [mention] Noah, when he called [to Us] before [that], and We answered him and saved him and his family from the great distress. And We gave him victory over the people who denied Our signs. Indeed, they were a people of evil, so We drowned them all." (al-Anbiya'/21: 76-77)

Allah's word about Pharaoh in Surah al-Qasas/28: 39-40:

"And he and his soldiers acted arrogantly in the land without right and thought that they would not be returned to Us. So We seized him and his soldiers and threw them into the sea. Then see how was the end of the wrongdoers."

All of that is a fitting reward for the mistakes they made, not injustice from Allah. He will not punish someone except those who commit reprehensible acts. Punishing someone without any fault is not in accordance with the sunnah of Allah that applies. Those mentioned in the previous verses were punished because of their sins and disbelief in Allah. In addition, it was also because they worshiped idols and denied the blessings given to them.
text.41:
Those who worship idols, viewing others besides Allah as their helpers and constantly hoping for assistance and protection from harm from them, are like a spider taking refuge in its web, which is so weak that it cannot withstand the blowing of the wind, nor protect it from the cold and heat. That web cannot fulfill its primary needs when it is needed. Such is the case with the disbelievers (mushrikun). They are unable to save themselves when Allah brings His punishment. Their protectors (other than Allah) will not be able to provide assistance. In fact, they themselves cannot avert Allah's torment from them.

In short, the idol-worshipping polytheist is no different from a spider building a web, which is very fragile and weak. The spider's web is like a very fragile house. Likewise, a very weak religion is a religion that worships idols.
text.42:
Allah is All-Knowing of what they ask of idols, statues, jinn, even humans. None of them can possibly provide benefit or bring harm to anyone unless Allah wills it. So weak is what they worship that it is like a spider that can only make a very fragile house.

Allah has the power to send down punishment upon whoever disbelieves. Therefore, the polytheists should fear Allah and hasten to believe in Him before His punishment comes, as He once sent it upon the people of old. When Allah's punishment comes, not one of their helpers (the idols) will be able to save them. Allah is always Mighty to destroy whoever deserves to be destroyed, and All-Wise to postpone the punishment for those who are expected to change for the better and steadfastly carry out that goodness.
text.43:
Thus does Allah set forth parables for mankind. Only those of understanding can contemplate these parables. Allah deliberately uses the spider as a parable, perhaps because it is easily understood by them. In addition to that, it is also intended to clarify all their doubts thus far. Those who always use their hearts and minds, and the experts in knowledge, will surely be able to understand the parable and will increasingly know the secrets of Allah contained in His verses. It is narrated from Jabir that the Messenger of Allah once said:

"The knowledgeable person is the one who safeguards the things from Allah, and acts in obedience to Him, and avoids all that incurs His wrath." (Riwayat al-Haitsami)
text.44:
The proof of Allah's greatness and majesty is visible in the creation of the heavens and the earth. For those who believe and use their intellect, all of Allah's creations contain wisdom and are not made in vain. Thus, the creation of the heavens and the earth allows humans to increase and expand their horizons of knowledge. In addition, their recognition of their Creator, namely Allah, will be more intensive.

According to scientific studies, Allah never plays around in creating everything. He does it "right," with *haq* (which can also be seen in Surah Ibrahim/14: 19). The word *haq* indicates something that is lasting, stable, so it will not change. It can be seen that the presence of all objects in the universe has a purpose. Not a single object is created by God without a purpose.

The planet earth with its sky (atmosphere), has been created by Allah with *haq*. The word *haq* means "correctly, precisely." How the truth and accuracy of His creation can be seen from the following description.

The Earth's atmosphere mainly consists of Nitrogen gas (N2" about 70%) which is not toxic to humans. This gas is very important in the growth process of living things, especially plants. While the other 20% is filled by Oxygen gas (O2) which provides energy for the metabolic processes of all creatures, through the process of breathing (respiration).

The distance between the sun and the earth is about 139 million km. This distance is considered appropriate because at this distance sunlight can function to help the life process. If the distance changes, whether moving away or closer, the effect of the light falling on the earth will be very fatal for living things. The temperature of the earth at the equator is also considered very moderate, which is on average between 28-350C.

In the description above, it has been illustrated that Allah created the earth not in jest. Everything is so precise for the beginning of life on this earth. How comfortable the earth is compared to some other planets in the same solar system can be seen in the description below. In the comparison made, especially on the distance between the sun and each planet, the effect of distance with each planet will be seen.
text.45:
This verse commands the Prophet Muhammad to always read and understand the Al-Qur'an that has been revealed to him in order to draw closer to Allah. By understanding the messages of the Al-Qur'an, he can improve and build himself according to Allah's demands. This command is also addressed to all Muslims. The appreciation of the divine word that is continuously read will influence the attitude, behavior, and character of the person who reads it.

After commanding to read, study, and implement the teachings of the Al-Qur'an, Allah commands Muslims to perform the obligatory prayers, namely the five daily prayers. The prayers should be performed according to their pillars and conditions, and with full devotion. It is highly recommended to perform the prayers complete with their sunnahs. If performed perfectly, the prayer can prevent and deter the person who performs it from vile and evil deeds.

Performing prayer is a manifestation of the belief that has been instilled in the heart of the person who performs it, and becomes proof that he believes that he is very dependent on Allah. Therefore, he strives as much as possible to carry out Allah's commands and avoid His prohibitions, according to the recitation of Surah al-Fatihah in prayer, "Guide us (O Allah) to the straight path, the path of those upon whom You have bestowed favor, not of those who have evoked [Your] anger or of those who are lost." He always remembers that prayer, so he does not have the slightest desire to commit vile and evil deeds.

Some scholars of tafsir are of the opinion that what protects the person who performs prayer from vile and evil deeds is the prayer itself. According to them, the prayer protects a person as long as that person maintains his prayer, as Allah says:

Maintain with care the [obligatory] prayers and [in particular] the middle prayer and stand before Allah, devoutly obedient. (al-Baqarah/2: 238)

Rasulullah saw explained the virtues and benefits obtained by those who perform prayer and the losses and punishments that will befall those who do not perform it, as mentioned in the hadith:

From the Prophet saw, that he one day mentioned about prayer, then he said, "Whoever maintains prayer, he will obtain light, guidance, and salvation on the Day of Judgment, and whoever does not maintain it, he will not obtain light, guidance, and salvation. And he on the Day of Judgment will be with Karun, Fir'aun, Haman, and Ubai bin Khalaf." (Narrated by Ahmad and ath-Thabrani from 'Abdullah bin 'Umar)

The Prophet saw also explained the condition of people who perform the five daily prayers earnestly, complete with their pillars and conditions, at the appointed times. Such a person, said the Prophet, is as if his sins are washed away five times a day, so that not even a little remains. Rasulullah saw said:

"What do you think, if there is a river near the door of one of you, he bathes in that river five times every day. Is there still any dirt left on him?" The companions replied, "There is no dirt left at all." Rasulullah said, "Then that is the parable of the five daily prayers, with which Allah will erase all his sins." (Narrated by at-Tirmidzi from Abu Hurairah)

Such is the parable given by Rasulullah saw about the condition of people who perform the five daily prayers earnestly only for Allah.

From the verses and hadith of Rasulullah that have been mentioned above, it can be concluded that there are three goals to be achieved by those who perform prayer, namely: 1) the emergence of sincerity; 2) the emergence of the quality of taqwa to Allah; and 3) always remembering Allah.

Prayer should be able to generate sincerity for those who perform it because it is done solely for Allah, to purify obedience only to Him. As a manifestation of this sincerity in a person is the emergence of a desire in his heart to do everything that pleases Allah.

Taqwa to Allah means the emergence of a desire for the person who performs the prayer to carry out all that Allah has commanded and avoid all that He has forbidden. With prayer, a person will also always remember Allah, because in the recitation of the prayer there are words of tasbih, tahmid, and takbir. He can also feel the majesty and greatness of Allah.

Allah threatens those who do not perform prayer with the torment of hell. Allah also threatens those who perform prayer for show and those who are negligent in performing it. Allah says:

So woe to those who pray - [But] who are heedless of their prayer - Who make show [of their deeds] - And withhold [simple] assistance. (al-Ma'un/107: 4-7)

In line with the verse above, Rasulullah saw said:

Whoever has performed prayer, but his prayer cannot prevent him from vile deeds and evil deeds, then his prayer will not add anything (to him), except that he is further away from Allah. (Narrated by Ibn Jarir from Isma'il bin Muslim bin al-hasan)

Furthermore, this verse explains that remembering Allah is greater. The meaning of this statement is that prayer is the most important worship compared to other forms of worship. Therefore, every Muslim should perform it earnestly. In other words, this sentence reaffirms the previous sentence which commands Muslims to perform prayer and explains the wisdom of performing it.

Ibn 'Abbas and Mujahid interpret the phrase "wa ladzikrullah akbar" (remembering Allah is greater) with the explanation of Rasulullah that Allah remembers His servants more than they remember Him by obeying Him. Nabi saw said:

Allah remembers you more than you remember Him. (Narrated by al-Baihaqi)

This is in accordance with the hadith qudsi of Nabi saw:

Whoever remembers Me within himself, I will remember him within Myself; and whoever remembers Me in a gathering, I will remember him in a better gathering than theirs. (Narrated by al-Bukhari from Abu Hurairah)
text.46:
In this verse, Allah guides the Prophet Muhammad and the Muslims regarding the content of their da'wah (invitation to Islam) and how to deal with the People of the Book, because most of them did not accept his call. When the Messenger of Allah conveyed the teachings of Islam, most of them denied him. Only a very few of them accepted it. Even though they knew Muhammad and the teachings he brought, just as they knew and recognized their own children.

Allah says:

Those to whom We gave the Scripture recognize him as they recognize their own children. But indeed, a party of them conceal the truth while they know [it]. (al-Baqarah/2: 146)

In another verse, Allah explains and clarifies the best way to conduct da'wah, as He says:

Invite to the way of your Lord with wisdom and good instruction, and argue with them in a way that is best. Indeed, your Lord is most knowing of who has strayed from His way, and He is most knowing of who is [rightly] guided. (an-Nahl/16: 125)

Inviting people to the way of the Lord with wisdom and good instruction, and debating them in a good manner, is done with those who do not commit injustice. As for those who commit injustice, namely those whose hearts have been sealed shut, who refuse to accept the truth, and who strive to eliminate Islam and its followers, they cannot be dealt with in the ways mentioned above.

The People of the Book who are unjust are those who have in their hearts the sickness of envy, hatred, and resentment towards the Muslims, because the last messenger and prophet was not raised from among them. They fight the Messenger of Allah and the Muslims by engaging in deception and slander, secretly and openly. They always try to hinder the da'wah carried out by the Messenger of Allah and his companions, such as making alliances with other disbelievers. There are many examples in history related to this matter. Therefore, they are called the unjust, and they strive to harm the Muslims. In the Hereafter, they will be the losers, receiving punishment commensurate with their deeds.

Furthermore, Allah warns that if the People of the Book invite the Muslims to discuss their holy books, and inform them of what should be affirmed and rejected, while they themselves know their own situation, then the Muslims should say, "We believe in the Qur'an which was revealed to us and also believe in the Torah and the Gospel which were revealed to you. The God whom we and you worship is actually the same, namely the One God. Therefore, let us together submit and obey Him and carry out all His commands and stop His prohibitions."

Regarding the meaning of this verse, Abu Hurairah said, "The People of the Book used to read the Torah in Hebrew and interpret it in Arabic for the Muslims. Then the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said:

Do not affirm the People of the Book and do not deny them. Say to them, "We believe in what has been revealed to us and what has been revealed to you. Our God and your God is one, and to Him we submit." (Narrated by al-Bukhari and an-Nasa'i from Abu Hurairah)
text.47:
In this verse, Allah explains to Prophet Muhammad that just as He had revealed scriptures to the messengers sent before him, so too did He reveal the Qur'an to him. In those scriptures, the coming of Prophet Muhammad in the future was alluded to. This then truly became a reality with the sending of Muhammad saw as the final prophet and messenger. The messengers of Allah were warned to convey to their people to believe in and follow the messengers who came later. Because, if a person believes in one of the messengers sent by Allah, then he is also obligated to believe in all the other messengers of Allah, both those who came before and those who came after.

Therefore, some of the People of the Book who lived during the time of Prophet Muhammad believed in him and in the Qur'an, in accordance with the commands of their prophets. They prioritized the afterlife over this fleeting world, and did not indulge in their desires. Among those who acted in this way were Abdullah bin Salam, Tamim al-Anshari, and others.

As for those whose hearts were diseased, such as being envious because the messenger whose coming was awaited was not from their group, or being deceived by the pleasures of the world because of indulging in their desires, they would deny the Qur'an, especially the verses that affirm the prophethood of Muhammad. The People of the Book should have paid attention to the calls and guidance of their messengers to worship Allah, and to believe that Muhammad is the final messenger and prophet. There is no prophet or messenger sent by Allah after him.
text.48:
This verse explains that before the Qur'an was revealed, Prophet Muhammad was well-known by the Arabs. He had lived among them for a long time before being appointed as a messenger. All the Arabs at that time acknowledged that Muhammad had high morals, was trustworthy, never lied, and was respected by his friends. They truly knew that Muhammad was not good at reading and writing, let alone composing storybooks.

Besides the Arabs, the Jews and Christians also knew from their books that Muhammad was a person who could not write or read. Mujahid said, "The People of the Book knew from their books that Prophet Muhammad could not write or read, therefore this verse was revealed." In another verse, Allah says:

(Those) who follow the Messenger, the unlettered prophet, whose description they find written with them in the Taurat and the Injil, who enjoins upon them what is right and forbids them what is wrong and makes lawful for them the good things and prohibits for them the evil and relieves them of their burden and the shackles which were upon them. (al-A'raf/7: 157)

In such a situation, Allah revealed the Qur'an to Muhammad. It contains a creed of very high value and is equipped with convincing evidence. The Qur'an also has a very beautiful style of language, so that no one can match it, even though at that time there were many famous literary figures among the Arabs because the art of literature was reaching its peak. However, very few of them believed.

If Muhammad saw could read and write, had studied with the People of the Book, or he was not a trustworthy person, did not have noble morals, and was not respected, then the disbelievers of Mecca would easily accuse and say that the Qur'an was made by Muhammad, not the Kalamullah (Word of Allah).

From this verse, it can be understood that the hearts and minds of the disbelievers of Mecca, based on their knowledge of Muhammad's personality, and the high literary value of the Qur'an, had believed in the Qur'an and Muhammad's prophethood from the beginning. However, because there was a disease in their hearts, and they were afraid that their position among their people would fall, they stated something that contradicted their own hearts and minds.

The meaning of *ummi* in this verse is not good at writing and reading. This does not mean that Muhammad was not knowledgeable, because Allah had taught him high knowledge, perhaps even knowledge that He had never taught to ordinary humans. Thus, he became a knowledgeable and wise person. Allah says:

And Allah has revealed to you the Book and wisdom and has taught you that which you did not know. And ever has the favor of Allah upon you been great. (an-Nisa'/4: 113)
text.49:
This verse affirms that the verses of the Qur'an are Allah's guidance, without the slightest ambiguity in their meaning. Allah makes its interpretation easy for those who seek the true truth. In another verse, Allah says:

And We have certainly made the Qur'an easy for remembrance, so is there any who will remember? (al-Qamar/54: 17)

The People of the Book who want to seek the truth can easily understand the Qur'an. Thus, they are willing to believe in it and believe that Muhammad is truly a messenger. Allah tells the Prophet Muhammad to say to the disbelievers who do not believe in his prophethood:

And those who disbelieve say, "You are not a messenger." Say, "Sufficient is Allah as witness between me and you, and [the witness of] whoever has knowledge of the Scripture." (ar-Ra'd/13: 43)

The meaning of the above verse is that the scholars of the People of the Book are witnesses to Muhammad's prophethood, because they have read about his coming in their books. Thus, there are among the People of the Book who believe in the Prophet Muhammad, including those who have been mentioned above.

Allah further affirms that the Qur'an is preserved in the hearts of Muslims. They memorize it from generation to generation so that no one can change it.

Furthermore, this verse explains that no one denies the verses of Allah except the wrongdoers. This verse is a hint to the People of the Book that they have known from their holy books about the prophethood of Muhammad and the revelation of the Qur'an to him. Nevertheless, many of them deny the truth after knowing it. Allah says:

But when there came to them that which they recognized, they disbelieved in it; so the curse of Allah is upon the disbelievers. (al-Baqarah/2: 89)

In addition to being a hint to the People of the Book, this verse is also a rebuke from Allah directed at the polytheists of Mecca who deny His verses. They do not believe in the Qur'an and the prophethood of Muhammad, which has become a clear truth. Allah calls these people wrongdoers. This characteristic of wrongdoing is the most appropriate characteristic for them because they hide the truth that they actually know. Allah says:

And who is more unjust than one who conceals a testimony he has from Allah? (al-Baqarah/2: 140)
text.50:
In this verse, Allah explains that the polytheists demanded that Muhammad show a tangible miracle like those brought to previous prophets, such as the she-camel of Prophet Saleh, the staff of Prophet Musa, and others. Their request was answered by explaining that the matter of miracles is Allah's decree. It was also explained their narrow-mindedness in rejecting a miracle of higher value and more suitable for them. They did not understand that the Qur'an is actually an eternal miracle, unmatched by anyone until the Day of Judgment.

This verse indicates that the disbelievers of Mecca denied the Qur'an as a miracle revealed to Prophet Muhammad. According to them, the Qur'an was not worthy of being considered a miracle, because a miracle should be something tangible, and directly seen and felt as was revealed to the previous messengers, such as the flood of Prophet Nuh, the staff of Prophet Musa, and so on. They stated that tangible miracles are easily accepted by the mind and can create conviction for those who see them.

Allah commanded Prophet Muhammad to answer the request of the polytheists of Mecca by saying that the matter of miracles is God's affair. He is the One who determines what miracle will be given to a messenger He sends, because it must be adjusted to the level of ability of the people who will witness it. Regarding the admission of the Quraysh that they could not accept the Qur'an as a miracle, Allah knows the contents of their hearts. Actually, their hearts had acknowledged the miraculous nature of the Qur'an as a miracle, but because of denial and the disease in their hearts, they did not want to say so. If they were truly going to believe with the descent of a miracle according to their request, of course Allah would send it down. There is nothing difficult for Allah, everything is easy for Him. Allah says:

And nothing prevents Us from sending signs except that the former peoples denied them. (al-Isra'/17: 59)

After the strange requests of the polytheists were answered, Allah commanded Prophet Muhammad to convey to them that he was only a warner to those who did not heed. His task was only to convey the message to them. He cannot change them into believers. Only Allah can do that. Allah says:

Whoever Allah guides - he is the [rightly] guided; and whoever He sends astray - for them you will never find protectors to guide them. (al-Kahf/18: 17)

Another saying of Allah:

Not upon you, [O Muhammad], is [responsibility for] their guidance, but Allah guides whom He wills. (al- Baqarah/2: 272)
text.51:
Ad-Darimi and Abu Dawud narrated that a group of Muslims came to the Prophet Muhammad bringing stories they had written themselves, some of which originated from the Jews. The Prophet (saw) said, "It is enough foolishness and misguidance for a people to reject what their prophet brought and desire something brought by a prophet who is not their prophet for others." Then this verse was revealed by Allah.

This verse is also a response rejecting the demands of the polytheists of Mecca who asked for tangible miracles. Yet the Qur'an had already been recited to them. Was it not enough for them the proofs that explain the evidence of the prophethood of Muhammad (saw), contained in the previous holy books, even though they themselves did not know them for certain? Did it not occur to them that a person who was illiterate, and had never associated with or learned from the People of the Book, was able to convey the Qur'an to them with content that was true, magnificent, and noble, and with such high literary value? If they were willing to think and desire the truth, the Qur'an alone would have been sufficient evidence for them to affirm the prophethood of Muhammad.

Then Allah explains the virtue and superiority of the Qur'an by saying that its verses are a mercy for them, because it does not contain threats, such as those given to previous peoples. Because they also denied, they should have experienced what was experienced by those who denied His messengers in the past, such as the people of 'Ad, Thamud, Pharaoh, and others. The absence of the threat of destruction for the polytheists in the Qur'an is a great mercy from Allah for the later Ummah of Muhammad.

It is also explained that the verses of the Qur'an are a lesson for those who believe. This means that the verses of the Qur'an explain the events experienced by past peoples, and their attitudes towards the messengers who were sent to explain the strong and complete evidence of the Oneness of Allah. The Qur'an also explains the noble character that a good human being must possess, explains the laws and guidance to achieve happiness in life, contains knowledge that is very useful for humans, and so on. If the polytheists and other human beings were willing to make these verses a lesson, think about them, and practice them, they would surely obtain the right path and be happy in this world and the hereafter. However, if they are unwilling and have no intention of removing the disease in their hearts, they will certainly be losers in this world and the hereafter.
text.52:
In this verse, Allah commands Prophet Muhammad to convey to the polytheists who still disbelieve in his prophethood that Allah knows and witnesses how he has carried out his duty to them. He has conveyed warnings and glad tidings to them, but they deny all of it. Allah knows their attitude towards the Prophet's call, even knowing the contents of their hearts. He will reward everything that His creatures do. If Prophet Muhammad were to lie and fabricate falsehoods against Allah, he would surely be afflicted with torment. Allah says:

"And if he (Muhammad) had made up about Us some [false] sayings, We would have seized him by the right hand; Then We would have cut from him the aorta. And there is not among you anyone who could prevent [Us] from him." (al-Haqqah/69: 44-47)

Allah explains that He knows everything in the heavens and on earth. He knows the condition of His creatures, from the subtle and invisible to the eye to the great. He also knows the condition of the polytheists and the believers. He also knows the accusations of the polytheists that the Qur'an is Muhammad's creation, even though none of them are able to match it. Those who believe in falsehood and deny Allah are those who lose their lives in this world and the hereafter.
text.53:
This verse explains that the polytheists knew about God's threat in the form of punishment that would befall them. However, they did not believe in the coming of that punishment, so they challenged that if the punishment was real, then it should be inflicted upon them immediately, as they said in Allah's word:

"Then rain down on us stones from the sky, or bring us a painful punishment." (al-Anfal/8: 32)

Allah's word:

"And they say, "When is this promise, if you should be truthful?"" (Yunus/10: 48)

Allah explains that the determination of the coming of the punishment is entirely in His hands; no one can know it. Allah has decreed to postpone the punishment until the time He has determined. If Allah had determined the time to bring the punishment, it would certainly come upon the polytheists suddenly, when they were heedless and unaware.

The postponement of punishment for the disbelievers certainly has wisdom and purpose. Among them is as a test for mankind, who among them is patient and who is not. For those who are patient, the test will strengthen their faith. While those who are not patient, then with the test they will return to disbelief or increase in their disbelief. Allah's word:

"And We will surely test you until We make evident those who strive among you [for the cause of Allah] and the patient, and We will test your affairs." (Muhammad/47: 31)

Sometimes the postponement of punishment aims to increase the denial of those who deny. Thus, they will be afflicted with a double punishment.

Allah says:

"Those who disbelieved and averted [people] from the way of Allah - We added to them punishment upon punishment for what corruption they were causing." (an-Nahl/16: 88)

Actually, there was a punishment that had befallen the polytheists of Mecca, but they did not realize it as God's punishment, namely their defeat in the Battle of Badr. At that time, they saw and felt how Allah had inflicted punishment upon them. However, Allah did not destroy all the disbelievers in that battle, as happened to the previous peoples.

Among the commentators (mufasir) are those who argue that Allah deliberately did not destroy all the disbelievers because some of them were still expected to have faith after the battle. These people were expected to become experienced Islamic soldiers to carry the banners of Islam, then continued by their descendants from one generation to the next that would come later, until the time determined by Allah. All of that happened according to Allah's plan and wisdom, which no one knows except Him alone.
text.54: This verse explains the consequences that the polytheists will experience due to their denial and ignorance. They will be cast into a fire that burns their entire bodies. This verse serves as a stern warning to the disbelievers by describing the punishment that will befall them in the Hereafter. This is because of their demand for the hastening of the punishment.
text.55:
This verse explains how the fire of Hell will burn the disbelievers in the Hereafter. All parts of their bodies will feel the torment, from the crown of their heads to the tips of their toes, from the visible parts of the body to the invisible. They will be enveloped by torment from all directions, from above and below, and from the right and left sides. In such a state, they will be told, "Taste on this Day the torment that was promised, as a consequence of your past deeds."

In other verses, it is explained how the fire of Hell encompasses the disbelievers. Allah says:

"For them there will be a bed of Hellfire and over them coverings (of Hellfire)." (al-A'raf/7: 41)

His saying also:

"They will have coverings of fire above them and coverings of fire beneath them." (az-Zumar/39: 16)
text.56:
In this verse, Allah commands His believing servants to leave their dwellings if they cannot fulfill the provisions of religion there and live in a state of oppression. This verse contains a universal principle stating that Allah's earth was created for the benefit of mankind. A person may live wherever he wishes if he feels safe in that place. In the new place, Muslims will find new brothers and families to replace the brothers and families they left behind, because essentially all Muslims are brothers, brothers in faith, sharing the same fate and struggle.

Another principle contained in this verse is that the Islamic religion tells its adherents not to be too fanatical about their hometowns and places of birth. The homeland must be defended, nurtured, and built, and the nation must be advanced. However, never let excessive concern for one's own homeland and nation result in harming other countries and nations. It is as if Allah is reminding us that the universe belongs to Allah and was created for the benefit of mankind. Therefore, humans are commanded to use this nature in accordance with the purpose for which Allah created it. No one should claim that something is their absolute property. A person's ownership of something is only temporary, and in time, that property will be taken back by Him.

The expression in the verse above also reminds Muslims of the vastness and abundance of Allah's possessions, so that they may look far ahead and not have narrow and limited views. That expression reminds Muslims not to only look at their own dwellings and assume that the earth is only limited to their places of residence. Such an assumption is wrong. Allah's earth is wider than they initially estimated. If they leave their own country and explore the countries of the world, they will certainly see and gain valuable experiences in that journey. They will also gain relief after hardship, and so on.

Allah says:

"And whoever emigrates for the cause of Allah will find on the earth many [alternative] locations and abundance. And whoever leaves his home as an emigrant to Allah and His Messenger and then death overtakes him - his reward has already become incumbent upon Allah. And Allah is ever Forgiving and Merciful." (an-Nisa'/4: 100)

Then, in a hadith, the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) said:

"All lands are the lands of Allah, and all servants are the servants of Allah, so wherever you find goodness (sustenance), then reside there." (Narrated by Ahmad from az-Zubair bin al-'Awwam)

Allah commands His believing servants to emigrate, leaving their hometowns, because He guarantees their lives on the earth to which they emigrate. Carrying out the command to emigrate, leaving one's hometown, is a very difficult command for someone to carry out, because it means separating from and leaving behind family and relatives. He also leaves behind the house and yard that he has long cared for and built, as well as his beloved possessions and livestock. He will separate from the country and all its contents, which have long seemed to be united with him, just as the body is united with its limbs. Therefore, Allah conveys the command to emigrate in a gentle and subtle tone, as if He is commanding them, "O My servants who have believed in Me, remember that I have created this vast earth for all of you. Therefore, utilize and inhabit that earth."
