In that call is also reflected the promise hoped for by those who emigrate, namely that Allah will reward their deeds for their obedience in carrying out His call. The reward is in the form of houses that are better than the houses they left behind, and wealth that is more blessed than the wealth they left behind. Likewise, their brothers and relatives will be replaced with relatives who are better and more noble than the brothers and relatives they left behind, as long as they continue to devote themselves to Him and carry out da'wah to mankind.

The Prophet (peace be upon him) and the Muslims fulfilled that sacred call. They emigrated to Allah, both individually and in groups. The first time they emigrated to Ethiopia (Habshah).*) There, Allah placed them in a noble place. Then they emigrated to Medina, which eventually became the place of emigration for Muslims, especially after the Prophet (peace be upon him) also emigrated there. In Medina, the Muhajirin (Muslims who came from Mecca) were received with open arms and joy by the Ansar (the original inhabitants of Medina who had converted to Islam), as if the Muhajirin were guests whose arrival they had been waiting for all this time. Their houses and wealth were shared with the newly arrived Muhajirin, who brought nothing from Mecca. In fact, it was seen that the Ansar prioritized the Muhajirin over themselves. The relationship between the two groups was so close that the Prophet (peace be upon him) made them relatives. Even at the beginning of the hijrah, the Muhajirin and Ansar groups could inherit from each other.

With the arrival of the Muhajirin, the city of Medina became more lively and developed. The city then became the center for the development of Islamic society, a gathering place for Muslims from all directions, and eventually became the center of Islamic government. The close relationship between the Muhajirin and Ansar groups was praised by Allah as a relationship that became the basis for the formation of Islamic society. Allah elevated the position of the Muhajirin because they had sacrificed all that they possessed for the sake of Allah's religion, while the Ansar were the helpers of religion. They were willing to spend what they possessed for the sake of religion.

Everything experienced by the Muhajirin after arriving and settling in Medina and mingling with the original inhabitants of Medina, namely the Ansar group, is proof of the truth of Allah's promise to them when they were commanded to emigrate to Medina.

This verse concludes with the words, "Therefore, worship Him alone." This sentence means that this earth is very vast and belongs to Allah. Wherever humans are and reside, that place belongs to Allah. Therefore, it is fitting for humans to monotheize and devote themselves to Him.

The verse above is a heavenly da'wah to mankind to free themselves, both physically and spiritually, from all kinds of attachments and material or spiritual shackles that can interfere with their movements and hinder their freedom.

In life anywhere and in any situation, humans will not obtain freedom, independence, survival, and the continuation of their true species, as Allah has determined, if they themselves do not strive earnestly in that direction. If they strive, they will certainly obtain it. Conversely, if they do not strive, it means they have wronged themselves and will not obtain what they want.

Islamic da'wah is to liberate mankind from oppression and error. Therefore, Muslims are obligated to wage jihad against oppression and error by sacrificing their wealth and lives. The jihad that is of the highest value and most important for a believer is the jihad that is carried out to free oneself from oppression and error, after which jihad is continued to others. A believer must free himself from all oppression that is degrading and humiliating, so he must eradicate both of these diseases. Allah says:

"Indeed, those whom the angels take [in death] while wronging themselves - [the angels] will say, "What [was] your condition?" They will say, "We were oppressed in the land." The angels will say, "Was not the earth of Allah spacious [enough] for you to emigrate therein?" For those, their refuge is Hell - and evil it is as a destination." (an-Nisa'/4: 97)

In the verse above, Allah promises a very painful torment in the afterlife to those who are vile and weak because they have degraded religion and underestimated themselves in the presence of the disbelievers. They are no different from merchandise that moves from one hand to another. They are unable to express their will and desires, let alone preach the path of goodness. Therefore, Islamic da'wah is aimed at liberating mankind, developing reason, and eliminating all kinds of pressure on the heart and soul, just as da'wah is aimed at maintaining the survival of mankind, as creatures created to worship Him.
text.57:
This verse reinforces the previous verse by explaining the essence of human life itself. It is explained that every human being will surely die, and after death, they will return to their owner, namely the Lord of the Universe. From the moment humans are resurrected in the afterlife, from that moment on they will experience true and eternal life. The form of that true life is determined by a person's attitude and actions during their life in the world. If they are a believer (mukmin), they will obtain eternal happiness, while if they are a disbeliever (kafir), they will experience a painful torment in hell.

This verse is in line with verse 185 of Surah Ali 'Imran and has been explained there, but it is repeated as a reminder to Muslims not to be too captivated and fascinated by the fleeting life of this world, because all of it is temporary pleasure and will end. The relationship between humans and everything they possess will gradually end. Let not a person's love for something prevent them from obeying Allah and His Messenger, because that thing is temporary. While what is eternal is only the result of a person's worship and good deeds (amal saleh). With all of that, they obtain the pleasure of Allah and the Paradise that He has promised.
text.58:
This verse explains the reward that will be obtained by those who believe in Allah, because they have emigrated for the sake of His religion. They have freed themselves from those who associate partners with Allah and dared to bear all the risks resulting from that emigration.

Allah's promise is to give those who believe and do good deeds gardens of Paradise filled with delights. In it are beautiful gardens with rivers flowing beneath them. They will abide therein forever.

Regarding the description of Paradise, it is explained by a hadith of the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him), in which he said:

"Indeed, the inhabitants of Paradise will see the inhabitants of the high places above them, just as you see the glittering stars passing on the horizon, whether from the east or from the west, because of the difference in their degrees." The Companions said, "O Messenger of Allah, those are the places of the prophets; other people will not reach them." The Messenger of Allah replied, "Yes, by Allah in Whose Hand is my soul, those are the places of those who believed in Allah and affirmed the messengers." (Narrated by Muslim from Sahl bin Sa'd)

In another hadith, the Prophet said:

"Indeed, in Paradise there are high places, the back of which can be seen through from the front, and the front of which can be seen through from the back." Then a Bedouin Arab stood up and asked, "For whom are those places, O Messenger of Allah?" The Messenger of Allah replied, "Those places are for those who are good in their speech, feed (the poor), fast regularly, and pray for Allah at night while other people are sleeping." (Narrated by at-Tirmidhi from 'Ali bin Abi thalib)

Such is the Paradise that Allah has promised to those who believe, do good deeds, are patient, and trust in Him.

In this verse, it is explained that Allah promises to give rewards to those who believe. Allah's promise is strengthened with an oath. This is to reassure the hearts of the Muslims, so that their steps are firm in taking the straight and difficult path, such as emigration and so on.
text.59:
This verse explains the reward that will be obtained by those who believe in Allah, because they have emigrated for the sake of His religion. They detach themselves from those who associate partners with Allah and dare to bear all the risks resulting from that emigration.

Allah's promise is to give those who believe and do good deeds gardens of paradise filled with delights. In it are beautiful gardens with rivers flowing beneath them. They will abide in that paradise forever.

Regarding the description of paradise, it is explained by a hadith of the Prophet saw, in which he said:

"Indeed, the inhabitants of paradise will see the inhabitants of the high places above them, just as you see the glittering stars passing on the horizon, whether from the east or from the west, because of the difference in their degrees." The companions said, "O Messenger of Allah, those are the places of the prophets, other people will not reach them." The Messenger of Allah replied, "It is possible, by Allah in whose hand is my soul, those are the places of those who believe in Allah and affirm the messengers." (Narrated by Muslim from Sahl bin Sa'd)

In another hadith, the Prophet said:

"Indeed, in paradise there are high places, the back of which can be seen through from the front, and the front of which can be seen through from the back." Then a Bedouin Arab stood up and asked, "For whom are those places, O Messenger of Allah?" The Messenger of Allah replied, "Those places are for those who are good in their speech, feed (the poor), fast regularly, and pray for Allah at night while other people are sleeping." (Narrated by at-Tirmidhi from 'Ali bin Abi Talib)

Such is the paradise that Allah has promised to those who believe, do good deeds, are patient, and trust in Him.

In this verse, it is explained that Allah promises to give rewards to those who believe. Allah's promise is strengthened with an oath. This is to reassure the hearts of the Muslims, so that their steps are firm in taking the straight and difficult path, such as emigration and so on.
text.60:
The *sabab nuzul* (reason for revelation) of this verse is based on a narration from Ibn 'Abbas, which mentions that the Prophet Muhammad said to the believers in Mecca, when the polytheists were torturing them, "Go forth and emigrate. Do not live as neighbors with those who are unjust." The believers replied, "O Messenger of Allah, we have no homes there, no wealth, no one to feed us, and no one to give us drink." Then this verse was revealed as an answer to the concerns of those believers.

This verse was revealed to reassure the hearts of the believers who answered the call of the Messenger of Allah (saw) to emigrate, both those who had already emigrated and the Muslims who were preparing to emigrate, as if Allah was saying, "O you who believe, challenge the enemies of Allah. Never fear poverty and destitution, for how many creatures are there that cannot gather food every day for their needs, yet Allah still provides for them. You, O believers, are far better than animals and more skilled at finding food, so why do you worry that you will not get food? Even if you emigrate without bringing anything, Allah will surely provide for you. Allah is All-Hearing of all kinds of prayers, knowing all the conditions of His servants."

This verse indicates to the Muslims that Allah will not neglect His creatures in the slightest. He presents an analogy easily understood by the Muslims, such as baby animals that cannot find food for themselves. Allah makes their mothers love them, so that they are willing to strive and struggle to find food for their offspring. Then the mother feeds the food she finds into the mouths of her young, as we see in birds and so on. There are also animals that feed their young with milk from their mothers, as is found in mammals. All of this is the decree of Allah, so that every creature can maintain the continuity of its species.

Similarly, with humans, some are strong, some are weak, some are rich, some are poor, some are small, some are large, some live in fertile places, and some live in barren places, all are given sustenance by Allah, according to their needs. This is what is meant by this verse. Allah provides sustenance to all His creatures, including the *Muhajirin* (emigrants), even though their possessions were left behind in Mecca, and their livelihoods were cut off.

Allah says:

"And there is no creature on earth but that upon Allah is its provision, and He knows its place of dwelling and place of storage. All is in a clear register." (Hud/11: 6)

Then this verse is concluded by affirming that Allah is All-Hearing of what His servants ask for and All-Knowing of all their needs.

From the verses above, it is understood that humans do not know for certain what they are doing. They only know their physical needs and requirements, while their spiritual needs, and others, are largely unknown to them, such as the need for air that they must breathe all day, water, and so on. Even so, every believer is obligated to strive and exert effort in their life. Allah has given the potential to will and strive, so we are still obligated to strive, as Allah says:

"Indeed, Allah will not change the condition of a people until they change what is in themselves." (ar-Ra'd/13: 11)
text.61:
This verse explains that the polytheists acknowledge that Allah, the One and Only, is the Creator of the heavens and the earth. He is the One who subjected the sun and the moon for the benefit of mankind. This acknowledgment of theirs is natural because initially, their ancestors adhered to the religion of *tauhid* (monotheism), namely, the religion of Prophet Ibrahim (Abraham) and Prophet Ismail (Ishmael). Initially, they were proud of this religion of *tauhid*, so they were not interested in Judaism and Christianity, which were developing in the Arabian Peninsula. As time passed and generations changed, without realizing it, elements of *shirk* (polytheism) gradually crept into the pure religion of *tauhid*. Because they indulged their feelings and desires, they gradually deviated further and further from the original foundation. Eventually, they worshipped idols, *jinn*, and other objects besides worshipping Allah.

Even though the belief they adhered to had deviated far from the religion of *tauhid*, they still acknowledged that they followed the religion of Ibrahim. If they were asked about who created the heavens and the earth and subjected the sun and the moon, they would answer, "The Creator is Allah, and Allah is the One who controls them."
text.62:
In this verse, Allah states that He is the One who expands provision for whomever He wills and restricts provision for whomever He wills. He alone has the power to determine provision, so believers do not need to be reluctant to migrate for fear of poverty. Allah provides sustenance wherever they are, whether in their own country, in another country, or on a journey, even when they are captured by the enemy.

Allah says:

Indeed, Allah is the Provider, the Possessor of strength, the Firm. (adz-dzariyat/51: 58)

This verse further states that Allah knows all the benefits for His creation. He also knows those who do good deeds because they are granted abundant provision, and He knows those who cause corruption and evil with the wealth that Allah has bestowed upon them.

This verse can also be connected to the statement of the polytheists in the verse before this (verse 61) where Allah states to the polytheists, "Who created and controls this universe?" They find no answer except to submit by affirming that Allah, the One and Only, created and controls all of creation. If they have acknowledged that, why do they still doubt who provides sustenance for all of creation? If they say that it is Allah who expands and restricts provision to His creation, and no one else, why do they still worship and ask for that provision from idols?

Allah further explains that He differentiates His servants in terms of the provision He gives because He knows best what is beneficial for them. The provision must be adjusted to their individual circumstances.
text.63:
In this verse, the question is still directed at the polytheists of Mecca. They are asked about who sends down rain from the sky, and then with that water, the land that had been barren and arid becomes fertile? What is their answer to this question?

In verse 61 above, they have stated that Allah is the One who created the heavens and the earth, and subjected the sun and the moon. This is something that does not need to be debated further because it is in accordance with sound reason and the teachings of the religion brought by Prophet Ibrahim, a religion that is recognized as their religion. However, their actions contradict the statements they utter. This is the strangeness that exists within them. Therefore, in verse 63, Allah explains that if they are confronted with this question, they will also answer, "Allah."

Thus, it is clear that they believe that Allah is the Owner of everything in the heavens and on earth. He is the One who controls everything in both, such as sending down rain from the sky, and then with that rain, the earth becomes fertile and grows plants. However, this belief does not underlie the deeds they perform every day, because they associate partners with God by means of idols that have no power or strength whatsoever.

Even though the polytheists make such an admission, most of them do not want to understand and practice that admission. They are as if they are ignorant people who cannot understand the essence of their admission. This is due to the error and injustice that have overcome the truth. When the truth is presented to them, even though their minds and instincts accept it, their hearts no longer accept it. They even accuse Prophet Muhammad of bewitching them, so that they doubt the reality seen by their own eyes and minds. Allah says:

"They would surely say, 'Our eyes have only been dazzled; rather, we are a people bewitched.'" (al-Hijr/15: 15)

In this verse, Allah commands Prophet Muhammad to say "al-hamdulillah". This statement is uttered as an expression of gratitude to Allah for the blessings He has given, namely the unveiling of the truth with the admission and statement of the polytheists about the Oneness of God. However, even though they have acknowledged the power and generosity of Allah, their hearts are still attached to the idols they worship.
text.64:
This verse explains the reality of worldly life, especially to the polytheists who are deceived by it. It explains that worldly life is merely play and amusement, not true life. The views and thoughts of the polytheists have been closed off, so they have been preoccupied with worldly affairs. They compete to seek wealth, power, pleasure, and the delights within it, as if worldly life is the true life for them. If they were willing to reduce their attention to worldly life even a little, and view it as a field of preparation for provisions in another life that is more eternal and everlasting, and were also willing to listen to the verses of Allah, surely they would not be disobedient and associate partners with Allah. If they listened to the call of the Messenger with their ears, minds, and hearts, they would not be led astray from the path of Allah.

Then Allah explains that the true life is the life of the Hereafter, and it is another side of human life, namely a life enveloped by absolute truth. Worldly life is a life in which truth and falsehood are mixed together, while in the life of the Hereafter, truth and falsehood have been separated. The life of the Hereafter is largely determined by the worldly life that a person lives, and depends on their deeds and efforts while they are alive. Worldly life can be likened to childhood, while the life of the Hereafter can be likened to adulthood. If someone in childhood prepares themselves earnestly, such as by studying and working diligently, then their adult life will be a bright life. Conversely, if they play a lot and do not use their time well, then they will have a bleak adulthood.

Such is the case with the life of the Hereafter, depending on a person's deeds and efforts while they are still alive in the world. If they, during their life in the world, believe and do righteous deeds, then their life in the Hereafter will be good and happy. Conversely, if they disbelieve and commit forbidden acts, they will experience a miserable life in the Hereafter.

At the end of this verse, Allah warns the polytheists to know the reality of life. If they delved into and knew this, surely they would not be led astray and deceived by this fleeting worldly life. Everyone who is knowledgeable and willing to use their mind can easily distinguish between good and bad, between right and wrong, and so on.
text.65:
This verse depicts the lives of the polytheists, which are full of contradictions and conflicts. Their hearts believe in the power and oneness of Allah, but the influence of the world and their desires obscure the true conviction in their hearts. Therefore, they cannot perform good deeds and remember Allah sincerely. They are like people lost in a life full of polytheism.

Allah likens them to people on a ship, sailing across the vast ocean. Suddenly, a fierce hurricane comes, accompanied by towering waves and swells, causing their ship to be tossed about. Fear arises in their hearts, accompanied by the feeling that they will not be saved and will be swallowed by the waves. At that moment, they remember Allah and believe that only He, the Almighty, can save and protect them from the crashing waves. They acknowledge the oneness of Allah, both in their hearts and feelings, as well as in their words. In short, in all their actions, they return to their original nature (fitrah), which is to acknowledge the oneness and power of Allah. They no longer believe that the gods they have been worshiping can release and save them from the impending disaster. Therefore, they pray and ask for help from Allah alone.

Then Allah answers their sincere pleas and prayers by saving them from all calamities. However, after they are freed from the terrifying disaster, and their hearts feel safe and secure, they immediately return to denying Allah who saved them. They forget that they once prayed to Him for safety and promised to remain submissive and obedient only to Him. They return to associating partners with Allah, with gods who are not worthy of being associated with Him in the slightest. So Allah lets them enjoy themselves until the appointed time, and Allah will give them a fitting reward in the Hereafter.

In another verse, the condition of the polytheists in the Hereafter is explained. They will acknowledge the oneness and power of Allah when they experience painful torment in Hell and pray for His help to be released from that torment. Allah says:

"Our Lord, bring us out of it, and if we ever return [to disbelief], then indeed, we will be wrongdoers." He will say, "Remain despised therein and do not speak to Me." (al-Mu'minun/23: 107-108)

Muhammad bin Ishaq in his book Sirah (tarikh Nabi Muhammad saw) narrates that 'Ikrimah bin Abi Jahal said, "When the Messenger of Allah conquered Mecca, I fled from him. When I boarded a ship to Abyssinia, the ship was tossed about. The passengers on the ship said, 'O friends, pray sincerely to your Lord, for indeed, nothing can save us from this disaster except Him.'" Furthermore, 'Ikrimah said, "If at sea there is nothing that can save except Him, then on land too there is nothing that can save except Him. O my Lord, I promise you, if I get out of this sea, then I will go to Muhammad and I will declare my faith in him, then I will find him to be very compassionate and merciful, and my promise will be fulfilled."

Ikrimah also said, "The people of Jahiliyyah, when boarding a ship, would also bring their idols. If a storm came, the idols would be thrown into the sea, then they would say, 'O Lord, O Lord.'"

Ar-Razi says in his book, al-Lawami, "This is a sign that knowledge of God is innate in humans. Although they are negligent in remembering Him in times of joy, they remember Him in times of distress."
text.66:
This verse explains the consequences of the polytheists' behavior of associating partners with Allah after they were saved from disaster, and it is a threat against their disbelief in His blessings. In the previous verse, Allah explained that after they were saved, they suddenly returned to associating partners with Him. This raises the question: why did He save them from the danger of drowning? Why wasn't the ship, along with all its passengers, allowed to sink to the bottom of the sea, thus ending their problem?

The answer is that it is natural for Allah, the Most Gracious, the Most Merciful, to grant the prayer of His servant who supplicates sincerely. They were saved as a test of their faith; whether they would remain in that faith or return to polytheism.

Apparently, this test did not yield results. After being saved by Allah, they returned to polytheism. They behaved in this way because polytheism had taken root and become deeply ingrained in their souls. This caused them to be ungrateful for Allah's blessing that had saved them from the disaster of drowning in the sea and allowed them to live comfortably in disbelief. Therefore, Allah threatens them by saying that they will know the consequences of that action in the future.

The phrase "then they will know (the consequences of their actions)" has a tone of threat to the polytheists, because the signs of Allah's power and oneness, as well as the blessings that have been bestowed upon them, cannot convince them, but rather increase their denial. It is as if it is said to them, "If they are negligent and do not change their behavior, they will know with certainty that the promised punishment will surely befall them." When the punishment has befallen them, all doors of repentance will be closed to them.
text.67:
This verse reminds the polytheists of Mecca of the blessings bestowed upon them. Allah distinguished them from the inhabitants of the lands around them by making the city of Mecca a safe, peaceful land where warfare was forbidden. Allah protected the city from enemies who sought to destroy and conquer it, as happened in the year of the Prophet Muhammad's birth. At that time, Abrahah's army riding elephants was destroyed by Allah before they could even touch the Ka'bah.

Allah says:

(1) Have you not considered, [O Muhammad], how your Lord dealt with the companions of the elephant? (2) Did He not make their plan into misguidance? (3) And He sent against them birds in flocks, (4) Striking them with stones of hard clay, (5) And He made them like eaten straw. (al-Fil/105: 1-5)

In another verse, the state of the city of Mecca and the life of the Quraysh are explained. Allah says:

(1) For the accustomed security of the Quraysh - (2) Their accustomed security [in their] winter and summer journeys. (3) Let them worship the Lord of this House, (4) Who has fed them, [saving them] from hunger and made them safe, [saving them] from fear. (Quraysh/106: 1-4)

On the other hand, the lands around Mecca were in a state of insecurity. Robbery, murder, chaos, and inter-tribal warfare were frequent, so people could not feel peace and security for their lives, families, and property. At any moment, the inhabitants were always worried about being attacked by enemies. In this verse, the polytheists are questioned whether they do not see this clear and obvious blessing? Do they not feel even a little that Allah has distinguished them from the inhabitants of the lands around them? Why do they not abandon the worship of idols that pollute the Ka'bah? In fact, the people of Mecca knew everything, but because of their denial, they believed in falsehood and denied Allah's blessings. How low their intellect is.
text.68:
This verse explains that the polytheists are extremely unjust people because they fabricate partners for Allah and claim that He has children. They are the ones who invent falsehoods against Allah and become His enemies. They make idols and then worship them to draw closer to Allah.

Allah recounts the beliefs of the polytheists in His word:

"Unquestionably, for Allah is the pure religion. And those who take protectors besides Him [say], "We only worship them that they may bring us nearer to Allah." Indeed, Allah will judge between them concerning that over which they differ. Indeed, Allah does not guide he who is a liar and [confirmed] disbeliever." (az-Zumar/39: 3)

After a messenger of Allah came to them, explaining the falsehood and invalidity of their actions, and showing the straight path based on truth, they denied and rejected everything. They even denied all the blessings of Allah that had ever been given to them.

Indeed, the polytheists have committed the greatest sin, which has no equal in this world. There is no appropriate recompense for them except the punishment of Hell in the Hereafter, and that is a fitting place for them.
text.69:
This verse explains the noble promise from Allah to the believers who strive in His path by sacrificing their lives and wealth, and enduring torment and obstacles. Therefore, Allah will guide them, help them strengthen their resolve, and provide assistance, so that they may achieve victory in this world and happiness and glory in the Hereafter.

Allah says:

"(They are) those who have been evicted from their homes without right, only because they say, "Our Lord is Allah." And were it not that Allah checks the people, some by means of others, there would have been demolished monasteries, churches, synagogues, and mosques in which the name of Allah is much mentioned. And Allah will surely support those who support Him. Indeed, Allah is Powerful and Exalted in Might." (al-Hajj/22: 40)

The meaning of jihad in verse 69 is to exert all kinds of effort to uphold the religion of Allah and elevate His word, including fighting the disbelievers who fight against Muslims. According to Abu Sulaiman ad-Darani, jihad here does not only mean fighting the disbelievers, but also means defending the religion and eradicating injustice. The most important thing is to enjoin good, forbid evil, and fight against one's desires in order to obey Allah's commands.

Those who strive are promised by Allah a wide path. This promise will surely be fulfilled, as He says:

"And We have already sent before you, [O Muhammad], messengers to their peoples, and they came to them with clear proofs. Then We took retribution from those who committed crimes, and it was an obligation upon Us to help the believers." (ar-Rum/30: 47)

This verse explains that those who strive in the path of Allah are those who do good (muhsin). This means that all kinds of actions, in accordance with what Allah has outlined in striving, are good deeds. It is called that because those who strive always walk in the path of Allah. Those who do not want to strive are not good people, because they have disobeyed Allah's command to perform jihad. That person is misguided, because he does not want to follow the straight path that He has laid out.

In this verse, it is stated that Allah is always with those who fight in His path, fighting against their desires, expelling all whispers of Satan from their hearts, and never neglecting the teachings of His religion. This statement can reassure the hearts of believers in facing the disbelievers and arouse their enthusiasm to strive in His path.

This verse explains that those who strive to seek Allah's pleasure will surely be shown His path. From this verse, it is understood that the vast field of jihad can be carried out in various ways, in the form of words, writing, and in certain situations, it can be done with weapons. Because the field of jihad is vast and numerous, it means that there are many paths that a believer can take to reach Allah's pleasure, as long as all these paths are intended to uphold truth, justice, and goodness.
